title: Setup Your AI Orchestration Stack
description: Learn how to choose and configure AI tools based on your data sources, understand connectors and MCP servers, and get your first agent running.

sections.heading: The Setup Mindset: Data Access First
sections.principle: Choose AI tools based on what data sources they can access, not on features alone.
content: Most professionals pick AI tools by features ('this has great summarization!') and then struggle to feed the tool their data. Smart orchestrators work backwards: identify your data sources first, then choose tools that can connect to them.

sections.heading: Understanding Connectors, Plugins, and MCP Servers
content: AI tools connect to your data sources through three main mechanisms. Understanding these helps you evaluate whether a tool can access your information.

tips.description: The AI tool has built-in support for specific platforms. ChatGPT has native plugins for Google Drive, Slack, etc. These are the easiest to set up—usually just OAuth authentication.
tips.example: Claude Desktop has native plugins for Google Drive. You authenticate once, and Claude can read/write files directly.
tips.lookFor: Tools that list your data sources in their 'Integrations' or 'Plugins' page.

tips.description: The tool can call APIs programmatically. This requires some technical setup but offers maximum flexibility.
tips.example: Make.com can connect to almost any service with an API. You provide API credentials, and Make orchestrates data flow between systems.
tips.lookFor: Tools with 'API' or 'Webhook' support, or Zapier/Make.com integration.

tips.description: A new standard for AI-to-data connections. MCP servers act as bridges between AI agents and your data sources.
tips.whatItIs: Your AI agent talks to an MCP server (instead of directly to your data). The MCP server handles authentication, data retrieval, and formatting. This creates a standard interface for agents to access many data sources.
tips.example: An MCP server for Gmail gives any MCP-compatible agent (Claude, GPT, etc.) the ability to read/send emails through a standard protocol.
tips.lookFor: Tools that support MCP or advertise 'context protocol' compatibility. This is cutting-edge (2024-2025) but growing fast.

sections.heading: The Setup Workflow: 5 Steps to Your First Agent
sections.intro: Follow this systematic approach to get from 'no AI' to 'first working agent' in under an hour.

steps.description: List where your work data lives. Don't skip this—it determines everything else.
tasks: Files: Google Drive, Dropbox, OneDrive, Box?
Project Management: Asana, Jira, Monday, Trello?

steps.step: Step 2: Identify Your Highest-Value Use Case
steps.description: Pick ONE routine task that involves data from the sources you just listed. Start simple.
goodUseCases: Summarize my unread Slack messages and email each morning
Pull data from Google Sheets and generate a weekly report
Search my Notion notes and Google Drive for information on X topic
Monitor my Asana tasks and notify me of blockers

steps.step: Step 3: Match Tools to Your Data Sources
steps.description: Research which AI tools can access your specific data sources. Use the catalog on this site to filter by your needs.
researchChecklist: Does the tool natively integrate with [your data source]?
Does it support MCP servers for [your data source]?
Do I need a middle layer (Zapier, Make.com)?

commonCombinations.tools: Claude Desktop with plugins OR ChatGPT Plus

steps.description: Sign up for your chosen tool and connect it to your data sources.
setupProcess: Subscribe to the tool (start with free tier if available)
Authenticate each data source (usually OAuth—'Sign in with Google')
Test the connection (most tools have a 'Test Connection' button)
steps.securityNote: Use read-only permissions initially. Upgrade to write permissions only when you trust the workflow.

steps.step: Step 5: Run Your First Agent Task
steps.description: Execute a simple test to confirm everything works.
testExamples: List my 5 most recent Gmail emails
Show me Slack messages from the last hour in #general
Find files in Google Drive modified this week
Summarize my Notion page titled X
steps.ifWorks: Celebrate! You've configured your first agent.
steps.ifFails: Check permissions, re-authenticate, or consult the tool's troubleshooting docs.

sections.heading: Tool Selection Decision Tree
content: Use this decision tree to narrow down your tool choices based on your data sources and technical comfort level.

examples.scenario: My data is all in Google Workspace (Gmail, Drive, Docs)
examples.topChoices: Claude Desktop with Google Drive plugin, ChatGPT Plus with plugins, or Google Gemini (native integration)
examples.reasoning: These tools have native Google integrations with minimal setup.

examples.scenario: My data is all in Microsoft ecosystem (Outlook, OneDrive, Teams)
examples.topChoices: Microsoft Copilot (native integration across all M365 apps), Claude/ChatGPT with Microsoft Graph API via Make.com
examples.reasoning: Microsoft Copilot is purpose-built for this ecosystem.

examples.scenario: My data is scattered across many platforms (Gmail, Slack, Notion, Asana, etc.)
examples.topChoices: Make.com or Zapier as the orchestration layer, connected to ChatGPT/Claude via API
examples.reasoning: These platforms specialize in connecting disparate services. You build workflows that pull data from multiple sources and feed it to your AI.
examples.setupTime: 45-60 minutes initial setup, reusable for future workflows

examples.scenario: I have technical skills and want maximum control
examples.topChoices: n8n (open-source automation), LangChain with custom MCP servers, or direct API integration to OpenAI/Anthropic
examples.reasoning: Full control over data flow, authentication, and agent behavior. Can build custom MCP servers for proprietary systems.
examples.setupTime: 2-4 hours initial setup, but you own the entire stack

examples.scenario: I just want to try AI quickly with minimal setup
examples.topChoices: ChatGPT web interface (upload files manually) or Claude web (paste text)
examples.reasoning: Zero setup. Start orchestrating immediately by copy-pasting data or uploading files.
examples.limitation: No automatic data access. You're the 'connector' manually feeding the agent.

sections.heading: Common Connection Patterns by Industry
content: Here are the most common data source combinations for different roles, with recommended setup approaches.

useCases.description: Typical data sources: Google Analytics, HubSpot, Social media APIs (Twitter, LinkedIn), Google Sheets, Slack
useCases.recommendedSetup: Make.com connecting GA + HubSpot + Sheets → Claude/ChatGPT for analysis. Use Make.com to pull data from analytics platforms, store in Sheets, then feed to AI for campaign insights.

useCases.description: Typical data sources: Outlook/Gmail, SharePoint, Airtable/Smartsheet, Zoom (transcripts), Survey tools
useCases.recommendedSetup: Microsoft Power Automate (for Outlook/SharePoint) + Zapier (for surveys) → ChatGPT API. Use Power Automate for document processing, Zapier for survey analysis.

useCases.description: Typical data sources: Jira, Confluence, Slack, Google Drive, GitHub, Mixpanel
useCases.recommendedSetup: n8n (self-hosted) with API connections to all platforms. Build workflows that aggregate: bug reports (Jira) + team discussions (Slack) + usage data (Mixpanel) → AI generates product insights.

useCases.description: Typical data sources: Salesforce/HubSpot CRM, Gmail/Outlook, LinkedIn, Calendar, Google Docs
useCases.recommendedSetup: Native CRM AI (Salesforce Einstein, HubSpot AI) + Claude Desktop for document drafting. Let the CRM's native AI handle contact data, use Claude for proposal/email writing pulling context from Drive.

useCases.description: Typical data sources: Zotero/Mendeley, Google Scholar, PDFs, Notion, Python/R notebooks, databases
useCases.recommendedSetup: Elicit (research-specific AI) for paper analysis + Claude for synthesis. Upload PDFs to Elicit for extraction, feed results to Claude for writing. Technically advanced users: custom MCP server for database access.

sections.heading: Troubleshooting Connection Issues
content: Even with good setup, connections sometimes fail. Here's how to diagnose and fix common issues.

examples.problem: The agent can't access my Google Drive
solutions: Did you grant the correct OAuth permissions? (Go to Google Account → Security → Third-party apps)
Does your organization block third-party access? (Check with IT)
Are you using the right Google account? (Log out and re-authenticate)
examples.insight: Most 'can't access' issues are permissions-related, not tool failures.

examples.problem: The API connection keeps timing out
solutions: Is your API rate limit exceeded? (Most APIs have limits—check docs)
Is the data payload too large? (Try smaller queries)
Does your firewall block the API endpoint? (Test from a different network)
examples.insight: Timeouts usually mean rate limits or network blocks, not broken integrations.

solutions: Is caching enabled? (Some tools cache data for performance—disable for real-time needs)
What's the data sync frequency? (Many integrations sync hourly, not real-time)
Did you refresh the connection? (Re-authenticate to force a fresh data pull)
examples.insight: Understanding data freshness expectations prevents frustration with 'stale' results.

examples.problem: I can't find an integration for my niche tool
solutions: Check if the tool has an API (build custom integration with Make.com/n8n)
Export data manually and upload to AI (less automated but works)
Request an MCP server (if the tool is popular, someone may build one)
Use Zapier's 'Webhooks' feature as a universal connector
examples.insight: Most modern tools have APIs. You can usually build a workaround even without native integrations.

sections.heading: Security and Permissions Best Practices
content: Connecting AI tools to your data requires careful permission management. Follow these practices to maintain security.

tips.description: Always grant read-only permissions first. Test your workflow thoroughly before giving write/modify access.
tips.reasoning: If something goes wrong, the AI can't accidentally delete or modify your data. You can always upgrade permissions later.

tips.tip: Use Service Accounts for Team Data
tips.description: Don't connect your personal account to shared team data. Create a service account with limited scope.
tips.reasoning: If you leave the organization or change roles, workflows don't break. IT can manage service account permissions centrally.

tips.description: Review what tools have access to your data every 3 months. Revoke permissions for tools you no longer use.
tips.reasoning: Access creep is real. You might have granted permissions to 10 tools and only use 3. Minimize your attack surface.

tips.description: Check each tool's data retention policy. Does it store your data? For how long? Can you delete it?
tips.reasoning: Some AI tools retain your data for training (though most enterprise tools don't). Know what happens to your information.

checklist.title: Complete Setup Checklist

items.task: Inventory: List all data sources you regularly access
Prioritize: Identify your #1 time-consuming routine task
Research: Find 2-3 tools that can connect to your data sources
Subscribe: Sign up for your chosen tool (free tier to start)
Connect: Authenticate and test each data source connection
Test: Run a simple agent task to confirm everything works
Security: Review and document what permissions you granted
Document: Save your setup steps for future reference
Iterate: Once working, add additional data sources gradually

checklist.footer: Setup is front-loaded work, but once configured, your agents can run for months with minimal maintenance. Invest the time upfront.
